Some treatments do indeed create more problems than they solve for individual people, and it would be great if we could know ahead of time precisely who they would/wouldn't benefit.  Maybe that is the place to concentrate - develop better screening or "matching" methods to know who has a very high probability of being helped or harmed.

column35: We need animal models to test how diseases, medicines, and other products will work on humans before we do human testing. Testing should minimize the number of animals needed and the harm done to the animals.   It makes sense for us to test new things in a layered way - simulation, against a culture, against an animal, against a healthy adult, and then against more vulnerable populations.
column40: Neither better nor worse for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: I think organic products are likely to be slightly better than those using "normal" fertilizers, pesticides, and preservatives. They also have lower yields and shorter shelf lives than non-organic products. I think both types of products should be available, so that people can pay more for organic options but have access to food whether or not they can afford the organic options.  We take a long time to figure out if new substances are harmful to humans (asbestos, PFAs, BPA, trans fars) and so it's hard to be sure how safe or dangerous products are until we've been making and using them in a consistent way for a very long time.

column85: I was very worried about "peak oil" and energy scarcity in the late 1990s, but I'm no longer concerned. We've made a huge amount of progress on solar and wind power and on utility-scale storage, and decent progress on higher energy efficiency, so it seems clear that we could transition to rely on renewable sources if we really needed to.  I thought we might not be able to run cars without oil (even if we had the energy needed as electricity) but electric cars with reasonable driving ranges now exist and are close in cost to gas-powered cars.  We also seem to keep finding more and more hydrocarbon reserves, pushing "peak oil" further and further into the future.

column29: It's true that side effects, high costs, and the industry's drive to treat symptoms instead of root causes have resulted in drugs and treatments that are expensive, invasive, and sometimes addictive. Still, there are an infinite number of opportunities and experiences to enjoy in the course of one's life, and you can't enjoy any of them if you're not alive. Modern medicine's ability to grant people the opportunity to enjoy these opportunities, in my opinion, outweighs its harms because I fundamentally believe life is precious and worth living.
column35: It's important to treat animals humanely, but it's also important to conduct research that can result in more humane treatments of billions of humans and, indeed, animals as well. For example, a drug tested on animals that cures some category of infectious disease may save many human lives, and may also be used on pets, livestock, and other animals as well. To let more humans (and animals) die to save a few feels more cruel on net.

column66: I believe legal immigration makes the economy stronger, which benefits all people in the country. column29: Although there are certainly problems, risks, and side effects that result from medical treatments, the benefits of treatments almost always outweigh any negative effects. For example, I have friends and family diagnosed with chronic diseases such as HIV, types of cancer, and diabetes. While they are unhappy with some of the medications and how if affects them, it has significantly improved their lifespan by decades, if not longer, and vastly improved their quality of life. It's also important to note that if someone doesn't want to pursue those treatments, we all have autonomy to make our own choices regarding our health and quality of life.
column35: Scientific research has had major medical breakthroughs as a result of animal experimentation, including findings not only in medicine but also in psychology and behavioral sciences. column29: Having been the recipient of medical treatments that drastically increased my quality of life, and having seen the lives of friends and loved ones saved or greatly improved by high quality medical care has given me the opinion that high cost medical treatments are worth it. Some of the kindest, most productive, charitable, and generally good people I know have had to undergo medical interventions to allow them to live comfortably. Without these treatments, they may have died and almost certainly would have been far less of a benefit to society around them.
column35: While I am im favor of the ethical treatment of animals of all types and very much against factory farming and dragnetting the sea, scientific research using animals is incredibly important. I believe that most animals have some level of intelligence, but not the same degree of consciousness as humans - so when it comes to saving or improving human lives, some mice or rabbits seem like a small price to pay in exchange for knowledge (both on what TO do and what NOT to do) that will be helpful to our species for decades or centuries. The continued advancement of humanity as a whole is very important to me.

Organic certifications are not perfect, but they at least provide requirements that ban the use of pesticides and herbicides that have the most potential for damage to humans and the environment.

column54: As the US federal government requires that we pay into Social Security for our entire working careers, then turns around and gives back significantly less money to each individual than we would have if we were able to simply put that same amount of money into an index fund instead, I do believe the feds are responsible for providing income in retirement for all Americans. The entire point of Social Security is to ensure that those of retirement age are able to continue to live somewhat comfortably, even if they were unable to save for themselves over the years. If the Social Security we have paid for the same protection against unforseeable financial ruin is not used to help retirees in general, why would we be forced to pay it?

column66: While blaming issues on immigrants is a long-standing American tradition, it is almost never the case. From the studies I have read, legal immigrants tend to fill roles at all pay levels and be more financially productive on average than US-born workers, bringing with them additional demand for products and services that bolster our economy as a whole. I have never heard of someone losing their job to an immigrant, or of anyone's wages being suppressed as a result of legal immigration. Everything negative I have heard about legal immigrants reeks largely of racist myths.
column79: So long as we are able to keep birth control legal, I do not believe population growth will be an issue in 2050. As the financial and climate landscapes look incredibly grim to many younger folk, fewer of us are willing to bring children into the world that will have to deal with an increasingly warming climate where food and water may begin to be a real concern within those children's lifetimes. I don't see overpopulation as an upcoming issue, as the US has so much unused or underutilized land that is good for both housing and farming, and technological advancements are making farming significantly more automated and productive over time.
column85: I believe that the recent work on AI, along with developments in renewable energy storage and small-scale nuclear power makes it less likely the world will face a major energy crisis in the next 30 years. I mention AI as the server farms required for AI require a TON of power, and there are already entire plants being built to feed these farms that can be switched back to feed the grid if required. In addition, even in 2021 there were 20 countries with over 90% of their total energy needs produced by renewables, and that number is steadily growing.

column29: Medical treatment often cause as many problems as they treat because if they cure an illness, sometimes they can create a new illness.  For example, treating someone with breast cancer with tamoxifen can also potentially allow the person being treated for breast cancer to have heart problems in the future and kidney problems.  So, if the person is cured of cancer, they have to go see a medical specialist for their heart as well.  Additionally, there could be other medical side effects to both breast cancer treatment as well as the needed future heart treatment.

column28: Medical treatments these days are worth the costs because they allow people to live longer and better quality lives
column29: I believe that while medical treatments are crucial, proactive health care is equally important in achieving long-term well-being. Regular check-ups, lab work, and screenings allow people to catch potential issues early, especially for managing pre-existing or genetic conditions. Alongside treatments, maintaining a healthy lifestyleâ€”through balanced eating, regular exercise, and stress managementâ€”creates a holistic approach to health. This combination of proactive care and effective treatments supports longevity and a better quality of life.
column35: I support the use of animals in scientific research because it allows us to test the safety, efficacy, and potential impact of treatments before they reach human trials. Testing on animals helps researchers understand how treatments might work in a living system, providing insight that's crucial for developing cures and effective treatments. While alternatives like clinical trials and volunteers who donate their bodies to research are valuable, animal testing can offer important initial information that guides safer and more effective human testing.
column40: Better for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: Yes, I do think organic fruits and vegetables are generally better for health because they're grown with fewer synthetic pesticides, fertilizers, and without GMOs. This can lead to lower exposure to chemicals, which may be beneficial in reducing certain health risks over time. Additionally, organic farming often emphasizes soil health and plant nutrient content, which could contribute to higher levels of some nutrients in organic produce.

column53: Yes, a responsibility of the federal government to provide for all Americans
column54: While I believe the federal government shouldn't have an absolute responsibility for retirement income, it has historically provided support through programs like Social Security. Given the increasing life expectancy and the rise of contract jobs without employer-sponsored retirement benefits, it's crucial to continue this support. Many individuals rely on these programs for financial stability in retirement, and since we pay taxes to fund them, it's reasonable to expect the government to maintain and adapt these systems to meet the evolving needs of the workforce. Stopping or reducing this support could lead to significant hardship for many Americans, especially as the job landscape changes.
column60: I believe that churches and other religious organizations should have some responsibility in addressing economic inequality, even if I'm not particularly religious myself. Religious institutions often serve as a moral compass, influencing community values and behaviors regarding ethics and morality. They can play a role in promoting compassion, generosity, and social responsibility.  To help reduce economic inequality, these organizations could implement community outreach programs, such as food banks, job training, financial literacy workshops, and affordable housing initiatives. By actively engaging their congregations in service projects and encouraging donations or volunteerism, churches can directly impact the lives of those struggling economically. Additionally, they could advocate for social justice issues and support policies that promote economic equity, further amplifying their influence in the community. Overall, while it may not be their primary mission, leveraging their resources and moral authority could significantly contribute to reducing economic inequality.
column66: I think the growing number of legal immigrants in the U.S. has a mixed impact on economic inequality. On one hand, they fill important jobs and contribute to economic growth, especially in industries like agriculture and healthcare. But on the other hand, if they're mainly in low-wage jobs, it can drive down wages for everyone and widen the gap between rich and poor. So, it really depends on where they work and how we support their opportunities.
column79: I think by 2050, the U.S. population will definitely grow, but not as rapidly as it has in the past. Immigration will play a big part in that, along with the birth rates and the aging population. Some cities will likely see a boom, while others may struggle to keep people around. It'll be fascinating to see how these changes affect different communities and the overall culture in the country.
column85: I think it's pretty likely we'll face a major energy crisis in the next 30 years. With the way the population is growing and our reliance on fossil fuels, it feels like we're just one shock away from a real problem. Plus, if we don't ramp up renewable energy and find better solutions now, we might be in for a rough ride down the line.

column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: The reason why I tend to be inclined to believe that generally speaking medical treatments cause as many problems as they solve is that in my experience, good physical health is first and foremost enabled by good psychological health, a phenomenon that isn't one of the underlying principles of western medical science but rather is typically thought of as being a separate field of knowledge.  As a result, medical science's tendency is to be reductionistic and non-wholistic in the diagnosis and treatment of illness, an approach which while uniquely equipped to address severe problems like heart disease and injuries caused by serious accidents of one kind or another, almost invariably falls short when it comes to more commonplace and fundamental ones.
column35: The reason why I oppose the usage of non-human animals in medical research of at least most kinds is that allowing data collection to take precedence over the well-being and quality of life of fellow sentient creatures, even if done in service of maximizing the safety and effectiveness of producs intended for human usage of one kind or another, is a form of exploitation and as a result cannot be considered to be an actually ethical course of action.

column54: The reason why I feel that the government has an ethical obligation to ensure that retired people are being provided with a sufficient amount of financial support is because quality of life just generally is enhanced when survival necessities are taking care of.  This is as a result of the fact that when people in circumstances of this nature, they are then able to devote more of their attention and energy to pursuits that enable them to make contributions to society as well as to increase their quality of life in ways that are more oriented to the more internal dimensions of the human experience.
column60: The reason why churches and other religious institutions should not be obligated to contribute to the alleviation of income inequality is that to do otherwise would be a clear breach of the principle of the separation of church and state.
column66: The reason why I believe that illegal immigration is not a major contributing factor to income inequality is that income inequality is based on more deeply-rooted issues in our economy and system of government and as a result, would almost undoubtedly still be present to at least a significant extent even were it the case that illegal immigration were no longer taking place.
column79: The reason why I believe that population growth isn't going to be a large problem by the year 2050 is because I think the current evidence suggests that by that time, renewable resources/energy generation technology will have been able to progress to a point at which even a population multiple times the size of our current one will be able to be supported without undue environmental destruction or the creation of impoverished conditions.
column85: The reason why I believe that we will likely not have to face a major energy crisis within the next 30 years is because I think that the evidence suggests that though historically we have not placed enough emphasis on the creation/discovery of renewable energy sources, there are enough efforts currently being made to sufficiently counter balance these missteps.

column79: Population growth is a significant problem in the US and worldwide, as we are living beyond the means of the planet to support us. column85: It is possible that there will be some technological breakthroughs and incremental improvements that will help us avoid a major short-term energy crisis. However, a major crisis of some type is inevitable, given population growth and increasing standards of living; it is only a question of how long until it happens. It is also likely that we will suffer a number of minor crises that will create problems but not be significant enough to cause us to rethink our current trajectory.

This is the opinion I've formed as a result of a few weeks of working in a nursing home where the elderly are being fed, bathed, "entertained" as though they were on a conveyer belt. It probably matters more in terms of lack of pesticides and other harmful chemicals that a food is organic if the food is something to be consumed raw and is without a peel. column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: If someone is cured of cancer, but then thousands of dollars in medical debt; what's the point? If someone is diabetic, has access to insulin, it costs more than they can afford; but their only option is to take it or die, so they go thousands into medical debt. When the cost of living is so high, it's cheaper to get sick and die than it is to continue to live. I had to go to the ER a couple of years back due to a stomach issues. The resulting medical bill has set me back to this day. I has to put it on my credit card or risk them sending it to collections, then I had to pay it off from my credit card to not affect my credit rating, accrued interest on it so I had to pay even more money, etc. My partner has cystic fibrosis. His main medication (Trikafta), cost almost $30,000 for a 30 DAY SUPPLY! That's only his main medication! His medication list is 6 pages long and he has to see a team of specialists every 3 months to ensure that the list of medications he's taking aren't killing his liver, since some of them have a chance of doing that! The only reason we can afford all of this is because he qualifies for disability and state medical insurance. He lost coverage at one point because he dared to try to have a job and the state kicked him off. The only reason he regained coverage is because he worked too hard and got sick, so he was once again unable to work and qualified. The current medical system is a for-profit joke that exists only to make the wealthiest of the wealthy even more so. They profit off of the poverty and death of us who are just trying to get by.
column35: While animal testing made sense before now, we've advanced past the need for it, and we also understand now that animals DO feel pain and distress from this testing! A medicine may show great promise in rats, but fail in humans. That's a waste of scientists time and effort, and a waste of whatever funding they received.

column29: I believe the costs of medical treatments are worth it because they enhance both longevity and quality of life. I've seen the relief effective medical care can bring to individuals and their families, and I value the role it plays in allowing people to live healthier, fuller lives. Investing in health aligns with my belief in the importance of community well-being and a dignified life for everyone.
column35: I oppose the use of animals in scientific research because I believe animals deserve respect and humane treatment, and subjecting them to experiments often involves unnecessary suffering. I feel that with advancements in technology, there are alternative methods we can pursue that don't involve harming animals, allowing us to balance scientific progress with ethical responsibility.
column40: Neither better nor worse for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: I think organic fruits and vegetables are neither better nor worse for one's health than conventionally grown foods because, from what I've learned, both types offer similar nutritional benefits. While organic foods may avoid certain pesticides, I believe that the differences in health impact are minimal, especially if both are washed and prepared properly. For me, a balanced diet that includes a variety of fruits and vegetables is what matters most for health, regardless of how they are grown.

column54: I believe the federal government has a responsibility to ensure adequate income in retirement for all Americans because, after a lifetime of contributing to society, everyone deserves financial security in their later years. Many people may not have the means to save enough on their own, so government support can help prevent poverty among older adults. To me, this aligns with the values of fairness and stability, promoting a society where everyone can age with dignity.
column60: I think churches and other religious organizations should have no formal responsibility in reducing economic inequality because individuals ultimately need to take responsibility for their own financial well-being. While social organizations can offer support to those in need, I believe it's not the role of either the government or religious institutions to ensure economic equality. Instead, people should be encouraged to rely on personal effort and resourcefulness to improve their economic situations.
column66: I think the growing number of legal immigrants working in the U.S. contributes a great deal to economic inequality because their presence can sometimes affect job competition and wage levels, particularly in lower-paying sectors. This influx can create disparities, as some industries may rely on immigrant labor to keep wages low, which can widen the gap between different income groups. column29: From my perspective, modern medical treatment, while incredibly advanced can sometimes bring about as many complications as they resolve. For every breakthrough medication or procedure that promise to alleviate symptoms or cure illnesses, there's often a side effect or unintended consequence that patients must manage.
column35: In my view, the use of animals in scientific research raises significant ethical concerns that can't be overlooked. Subjecting animals to testing often involves pain, stress, and confinement, and it feels inherently wrong to put sentient beings through such suffering for human gain. While some argue that animal research is necessary for medical advancements, I believe that we should invest more in alternative methods, like computer modelling and lab-grown cells, which an provide reliable results without causing harm.

column54: I strongly feel that the federal government has a responsibility to ensure adequate income for all Americans in retirement. After decades of contributing to society through work, people deserve financial security in their later years, especially as costs for healthcare, housing, and daily living continue to rise. Relying solely on personal savings and investments is often unrealistic for many, given economic uncertainties and wage disparities. A strong government-backed retirement system, such as Social security, serves as a safety net, reducing the burden on individuals and families and preventing elderly poverty.
column60: I believe that churches and other religious organization can play a significant role in reducing economic inequality in our country. Many religious institutions are deeply rooted in communities and have a mission of services, often with resources and networks that can support those in need. Through charitable programs, job training, and direct assistance to low-income families, these organization can help bridge gaps in government aid.
column66: I think, the growing number of legal immigrants working in the US doesn't necessarily contribute to economic inequality; in fact, they often play a crucial role in the economy. Immigrants typically fill diverse roles, from highly skilled positions to essential labor jobs, driving growth and innovation while meeting labor demands in sectors where there are shortages.
column79: I think that by 2050, population growth in the US could present certain challenges, but it may not necessarily become a "major problems" if we plan ahead. Population increases can strains resources like housing, healthcare, and infrastructure, especially in densely populated urban areas. However, with thoughtful urban planning, sustainable resources management, and investment in renewables energy and technology, the country can manage these demands.
column85: I personally believe that the world is likely to face a major energy crisis within the next if we don't shift our approach to energy production and consumption. column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: The reason I feel that medical treatments create more problems is because I have had many family members seek treatment for things like cancer or heart problems and eventually die from the same ailment or end up with new issues. Specifically, I had a really close friend who developed a kidney disease fairly young. He was on the waitlist for a transplant for nearly 10 years. During that time, he was doing dialysis at home himself. He finally got a transplant and proceeded to live 5 months before he died. It's almost as if he were better off doing the dialysis himself instead of getting the transplant. A small example for myself is how I was told I have high blood pressure earlier this year and started taking medication to lower it. Now I have all of these symptoms from the medication like coughing and dizziness. It just seems like a money grab.

column29: While medical science is not perfect, and don't get me started on the obscene cost of healthcare in America, it is undeniable that people are living longer and healthier lives today than they were, say, 100 years ago. Much of that is due to the medical interventions early in life (vaccines, regular pediatrician visits), cancer screening, and improvement in medical treatments for a host of conditions that would have killed our great grandparents, but we can live normal lives with. I would especially point out treatments for HIV. A generation ago, it was a death sentence. Today, the condition is commonly managed with medication and people live normal lives.

column28: Medical treatments these days are worth the costs because they allow people to live longer and better quality lives
column29: Medical treatments have greatly improved in the past 100 years, and people generally have a much improved quality of life nowadays. Medical costs have also skyrocketed, but not everyone has equal access to medical care. For someone like me who has good health insurance, the costs aren't great, but manageable, and many medical treatments are worth it. For others, the costs are so out of control that almost no medical treatment is worth the cost. In general, especially in countries with more equitable access to healthcare, the treatments are worth the costs.

I do not understand why people hate on immigrants so much, and I actually think that we should increase legal migration, even converting illegal immigrants (who are only illegal because they don't have a legal path to migration) to legal immigrants.
column79: The rate at which the world's population is growing has been slowing and is projected to stop around 2050. I think the US population will continue to increase after that point due to immigration because people want to move to a place where they can be prosperous.  So while I don't think the country in general will be overcrowded, I think that population will continue to concentrate into large urban areas, as has been the trend in the past couple decades. Nobody will want to live in small town Kansas because no jobs will be there. That will drive real estate costs and the cost of living really high as people complete for living space within commuting distance from their jobs. So unless we really rethink population density (like more tall residential buildings) and efficient public transportation, I think that will pose the biggest problem.
column85: I've been hearing an energy crisis predicted since the 1980s and it hasn't come to pass. We keep managing to find ways to avoid an energy crisis. Back then, we were reliant on oil for almost everything. Nowadays, we have more energy sources like solar and wind, and we have more electric vehicles, so we can more easily diversify our energy sources. So I think it's actually looking better for energy than it has for a long time. An energy crisis, if it comes, would be from insufficient investment in energy infrastructure, not running out of oil.

For instance, I know people who have had lifesaving surgeries or who had to fight to get access to expensive medications that have helped them - such as people who are using ketamine for depression and other mental health issues, or I heard from my neurologist that he often has people do once a month injection medications that are a newer line medication, even though it costs a lot more, because he's seen these are more effective with fewer side effects than more traditional cheaper pills.

column29: Medical treatments can cause serval issues both physically and financially. Financially, neither the hospital NOR the insurance company have to disclose the estimated or final cost, nor an itemized list of services and products provided, and they can charge almost indiscriminately, meaning that the financial burden lies on the patient. Physically, a lot of the treatments may solve a singular issue or symptom and cause additional problems. For example, Tomoxzfin, a popular drug used to treat breast cancer, actually has a high correlation of uterine cancer with use.

column41: Since organic food is, supposedly, grown without the use of synthetic hormones, fertilizers, pesticides and other additives I think there is a conclusion to be made that it is better for one's health.  Every person who consumes non-organic foods is consuming an unknown amount of these additives. There's no way to conclusively know which persons will be the ones negatively affected.

column28: Medical treatments these days are worth the costs because they allow people to live longer and better quality lives
column29: Thinking about historical development of medicine, I think it's pretty clear that as medical treatments were developing, so was the quality and length of life. For example, vaccines (like measles or Covid-19) helped save lives of many people; non-invasive surgeries like LASIK help people perform professional duties better and ensure a higher quality of life; and there are many other examples. Today, there is also research being done on how to rectify some genetic issues in human bodies, and I believe this will help us live even longer and happier lives in the future since people won't suffer from diseases as much.
column35: While I believe that it is important to be as humane as possible in scientific research, I put human life and well-being above all. If we can use a dozen animals to find a drug that would have a potential to reduce human suffering and save many lives, it is absolutely worth it. I recognize that this belief is not shared by everyone, and I do believe that where possible animal suffering in the process should be reduced also.
column40: Better for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: I am not a scientist or an expert, but I do think that organically grown foods are healthier as they contain fewer pesticides and other harmful chemicals. There's a reason many of the food additives and chemicals are banned in places like the European Union, and yet we use them here in the US, while organic food is much more expensive. I believe that our country needs to reassess the sales of non-organic foods and consider making organic options more accessible.

column54: I think the system should be be voluntary - people should be able to opt into private options for retirement savings, but for lower-income citizens the government should provide a retirement safety net (similar to how we can opt for a health insurance or have one provided by the government). This will ensure that we're not creating an inefficient system but are only giving benefits to those who need them. It's important that every person has proper life conditions and some dignity.
column60: While I don't think religious organizations have a direct responsibility like the government, they can still be a catalyst for change by setting up nonprofits, hospitals etc. They can also redistribute voluntary donations within congregations to those who need support.
column66: While one can make an argument that "immigrants are stealing jobs", our growing economy does require a constant state of growth which cannot be sustained by only using native population which is shrinking. Thus, having a prosperous economy supported by legal immigrants is crucial for national prosperity. Now, what we do with that prosperity and how we distribute wealth is a different story, but without economic growth enabled by immigration there would be nothing to distribute.
column79: We can see that the birth rates are currently below the replacement rate (e.g. 2 kids per family), and the population growth in the US is only sustained with the help of immigration. We don't know if that will be the case in 2050, so there's a need to find solutions to grow the population internally without outside sources just in case.
column85: Energy crises happen fairly often - like when oil prices go up, or a major energy source is lost (like in case of sanctions against Russia). Besides, we are facing a climate change threat, so I do believe that in 30 years we'll experience some kind of crisis.

column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: It was a hard choice between my selection and the first answer because I do see a lot of merit and positive outcomes overall when it comes to medical treatments. I've been lucky enough to have needed minor treatments and vaccinations which have all gone well. However, I've personally witnessed numerous friends and relatives endure negative outcomes from pharmaceuticals, major and minor surgeries, and outpatient procedures.
column35: Again, this was a difficult decision. While I see the overall merit in using animals for scientific research, regulations should be more strict as far as what products require testing and quality of life/respect for the test animals and their mothers. We should also utilize the minimal amount of animals necessary for thorough testing. The type of animal should be considered as well; I am very against Beagle testing, hesitant but understanding of primate testing, and cautiously condone testing on rodents. We should not be using animals to test shampoos and personal products that contain over the counter ingredients. For personal products that use a drug product, using animals for scientific research should be done with oversight that requires a plan for causing the least amount of harm and distress to the least amount of animals necessary to analyze a genuine medical concern for humans, with a clear goal in mind for scientific progress.
column40: Neither better nor worse for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: Pesticides can still be used on organic foods. There is no agreed upon legal definition for organic.  While organic products are often of a higher quality, you can't be certain of what it may have been treated with, although it's unlikely you'd have to be concerned about Monsanto products. Sometimes the quality is no better than commercial products; the term organic can often just be a marketing term due to no (or loose) regulations on selling products with that label.

column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: Many of the medical treatments have too many side effects that are often worse than the treatment itself.  One of them was the COVID vaccine.  My wife, who was already chronically ill, took the vaccine in 2021.  She already had high blood pressure from diabetes, and the vaccine seemed to make it worse.  Less than three she was after getting the vaccine, she died from a brain hemorrhage.  Before she took the vaccine, she was were able to control her blood pressure but it became much more difficult after she took the vaccine.  I also had other friends and family members who got sick after taking the vaccine.  This is one of several reasons why I never took the vaccine.

column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: I have seen many people receive treatments for serious medical problems, only to have treatment cause other issues which then require treatment, too. A good friend of mine needed hip surgery, and she did not recover as expected. Through further tests it was discovered that she had endometrial cancer. She then had to undergo surgery, chemo and radiation. She remained sick all through this time and after, with intestinal issues and more. Routine scans seemed positive, but she continued to feel horrible. She also started getting more pain, this time from the other hip, so it was scheduled to be replaced. During surgery, it was found that she had invasive cancer in muscle near her hip. Not sure how a full body scan just a few months prior missed that. She never recovered from the 2nd hip replacement and became so week that they would not even consider her for any kind of cancer treatment. She died just a few months later at a family member's home. All those years of pain and suffering through the surgeries and treatments were all for nothing. She never got her life back even to a small degree from the time she was originally diagnosed. I've also seen relatives get cutting edge treatments that made sick in other ways, and then those things had to be treated.
column35: Animal's bodies are not the same as humans' bodies. column35: I oppose the use of animals in scientific research because I believe animals deserve ethical treatment and should not suffer for experiments. column91: We received a 'classicial education' until 1970, like the village school in Britain until 1970 -- this classical, local school was the type that had educated Shakespeare. We were angry to discover the courses we'd had in public high school were the same as freshman and sophomore years in college. After 1970 in both US and GB, national, centralized government  schools were called 'comprehensive' schools -- bare minimum to function in society. A middle school principal was gobsmacked in 1984 when I asked if the middle school offerred Latin for my daughter as I'd had 20+ years before. Teachers' unions and Department of Education has done more to destroy US education than anything else I can think of -- ever-increasing funds spent and since 1970, more and more little Johnnys and Janies can't even read, write, add, subtract, multiply, or divide.

GMO's are like MSG, something that is used to better food but was demonized for whatever reason connected to health. GMO's aren't even that dangerous because of the fact that they are *genetically* altered and not physically or chemically, and the alterations aren't enough to make them an entirely new fruit. column28: Medical treatments these days often create as many problems as they solve
column29: Modern medical treatments can cause problems alongside their benefits due to side effects, drug interactions, and the body's complex responses. Overprescription, reliance on symptom management rather than cures, and systemic issues in healthcare can exacerbate these challenges. While advancements save lives, a personalized and preventive approach is essential to minimize unintended consequences.
column35: Animal research is often seen as unethical because it can cause pain and suffering to sentient beings. Biological differences between animals and humans mean that results may not reliably translate to human treatments, leading to wasted resources or ineffective solutions. With advancements in alternatives like computer models and tissue engineering, many argue that we should move away from animal testing entirely.
column40: Better for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: Organic food is often considered better because it is grown without synthetic pesticides, fertilizers, or genetically modified organisms, which may reduce exposure to harmful chemicals. Additionally, organic farming practices are designed to be more environmentally sustainable, promoting soil health and biodiversity.

By providing a safety net, the government helps prevent poverty among retirees and reduces the burden on families and communities.

column28: Medical treatments these days are worth the costs because they allow people to live longer and better quality lives
column29: I believe that modern medical treatments are worth the cost because they significantly improve people's well-being and extend their lives. For example, advances in treatments for chronic conditions like diabetes or heart disease have allowed many individuals to live active, fulfilling lives that would have been impossible a few decades ago. Personally, I've witnessed the positive impact of these treatments on family members, which has reinforced my belief in their value. Additionally, knowing that medical advancements can prevent suffering or even save lives makes me feel that investing in healthcare is ultimately beneficial for society as a whole.
column35: I favor the use of animals in scientific research because many important medical breakthroughs have been made possible through animal studies, improving human health and saving lives. For example, without animal testing, we wouldn't have developed critical treatments for diseases like cancer, HIV/AIDS, or diabetes. While I understand the ethical concerns, I believe that with strict guidelines and regulations to ensure humane treatment, animal research can be conducted responsibly to benefit both human and animal welfare. Ultimately, the potential for advancing science and medicine justifies the careful and ethical use of animals in research.
column40: Better for one's health than conventionally grown foods
column41: I believe organic fruits and vegetables are generally better for one's health because they are grown without synthetic pesticides and fertilizers, which some studies suggest could have long-term health risks. Personally, I've noticed a difference in taste and quality when eating organic produce, which makes me feel more confident about what I'm consuming. Additionally, I value the environmental benefits of organic farming, such as reduced chemical runoff and healthier soil, which contribute to overall well-being. While I understand that the health benefits of organic foods can be debated, I feel that choosing organic is a way to prioritize both personal health and environmental sustainability.

column53: Yes, a responsibility of the federal government to provide for all Americans
column54: I believe it is not the federal government's responsibility to provide adequate income in retirement because individuals should take personal responsibility for their financial future. Retirement planning, such as saving and investing, is a personal choice, and I think people should be encouraged to make their own decisions about how to prepare for retirement. While government programs like Social Security can offer a safety net, I feel that the primary responsibility for retirement savings lies with individuals and families. Additionally, relying on the government for such support could lead to an unsustainable system and disincentivize personal financial planning.
column60: I believe churches and religious organizations should have some responsibility in reducing economic inequality because they often play a key role in supporting their communities through charity, education, and social services. Many religious teachings emphasize caring for the poor and helping those in need, so it's natural for these organizations to take part in efforts to reduce inequality. However, I don't think they should bear the entire burden, as addressing economic inequality is a broader societal issue that requires action from governments, businesses, and individuals as well. While churches can offer significant support, I feel it's important for the government and other institutions to also play their part in creating systemic change.
column66: I believe the growing number of legal immigrants working in the U.S. contributes only marginally to economic inequality because immigrants often fill labor gaps in industries that rely on low-wage workers, such as agriculture, construction, and service sectors. While they may be paid lower wages, they also contribute to the economy by providing essential services and boosting productivity. Additionally, many immigrants eventually contribute to the economy in more significant ways as they integrate into the workforce, start businesses, and pay taxes. Overall, I think other factors like wage stagnation and automation play a much larger role in economic inequality than immigration itself.
column79: I believe population growth in the U.S. in 2050 will not be a problem because the country has a history of adapting to demographic changes through innovation and policy adjustments. While there may be challenges, such as ensuring adequate infrastructure and resources, the U.S. has the capacity to manage population growth by leveraging technology, improving efficiency, and addressing social needs. Additionally, immigration can help offset labor shortages and sustain economic growth, contributing to the country's long-term stability. Overall, I see population growth as a manageable challenge rather than a crisis.
column85: I believe the world will definitely face a major energy crisis in the next 30 years due to the growing demand for energy, the depletion of fossil fuel reserves, and the slow transition to renewable energy sources. While renewable technologies like solar and wind are advancing, they still face challenges such as storage and infrastructure limitations. Additionally, political and economic factors often hinder the shift away from fossil fuels, which could exacerbate shortages. Given these factors, I think a major energy crisis is likely unless significant changes are made to how we produce and consume energy.
column90: The public education system will improve
column91: I believe the public education system in the U.S. will improve in the next 30 years because there is increasing recognition of the need for reform and investment in education. With advancements in technology, new teaching methods, and a growing emphasis on equity, the system has the potential to adapt and better serve diverse student populations. Additionally, more people are advocating for changes in how schools are funded and structured, which could lead to positive reforms. While challenges remain, the growing focus on educational improvement gives me hope for meaningful progress.
